In due course, they were informed that the invention would not be offered to the British Government because it was utterly useless. They then came to the Attorney-General's Department again, and pointed out that there was now no objection to patent rights being issued to them. At this stage, there appeared to be no further trouble; but when they went to the Treasurer for permission to float the invention into a company, and asked for a large proportion of the shares in the proposed company, the Treasury replied that it was prepared to grant a much smaller sum to prove the scheme before authorizingthe formation of a company to develop it on a large scale. I looked through the papers, and found that a prima facie case for the success of the in vention had been made out. Two persons had used the substitute for petrol, one in a special carburetter, and the other in an ordinary carburetter. Both had taken records of the engine revolutions with Vwo fuels, and, according to their statement, the substitute for petrol gave very satisfactory results. One would imagine that, with this evidence before the Department, the officials would be keen, in the public interest, to facilitate any action in the direction of proving the invention, because the matter is of the greatest public importance, especially in view of the fact that the material from which this spirit may be generated is now running to waste in Australia. It was suggested to me that this syndicate was being well treated by the Department, and I will endorse that statement if the Department will tell me what proof it requires. I think I may be pardoned for suggesting to the Treasurer that to proceed by this method in a matter of such importance is to travel with much energy, but no progress, in a vicious circle. I am not concerned with the syndicate- I do not know them, and I am not sure if I have seen any of the men-bu t I think that if the results, claimed for this invention can be obtained we shall, by developing it, ,be doing more towards winning the war than by talking from now onwards t ill the conclusion of the war. If the Department thinks the invention will be an advantage to the country, but that tihe persons concerned are grasping, and are pushing the invention for their personal benefit, the Government should step in , take it over, and pay the inventors such a sum as an arbitrator may determine. The public weal should not be prejudiced either by departmental procrastination- I am not blaming the Treasury, because that Department is the least offender in this business-o r by this interlocking of departmental energy, which always results in an enormous waste of departmental paper. May I suggest to the Treasurer, that, in cases where money is required for the development of a venture which means so much for the welfare of Australia, the Department should state definitely what proof is required, and the method by which it may be obtained ? If this is done, Ministers will short-circuit much of this departmental correspondence, and we shall remove the stigma which rests upon Australian administration that after three years of war it has not been responsible for one new thought for the benefit of our common cause.
